str2: For. A primary particle; properly, assigning a reason.

parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Plural
str2: To follow after, imitate. From ek and akoloutheo; to follow out, i.e. to imitate, obey, yield to.

parse: Verb - Perfect Participle Middle or Passive - Dative Masculine Plural
str2: From sophos; to render wise; in a sinister acceptation, to form 'sophisms', i.e. Continue plausible error.
An idle tale, fable, fanciful story. Perhaps from the same as mueo; a tale, i.e. Fiction.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 1st Person Plural
str2: To make known, declare, know, discover. From a derivative of ginosko; to make known; subjectively, to know.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From dunamai; force; specially, miraculous power.
From the present participle of pareimi; a being near, i.e. Advent; physically, aspect.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 1st Person Plural
str2: I, the first-person pronoun. A primary pronoun of the first person I.
Lord, master, sir; the Lord. From kuros; supreme in authority, i.e. controller; by implication, Master.
Of Hebrew origin; Jesus, the name of our Lord and two other Israelites.
Anointed One; the Messiah, the Christ. From chrio; Anointed One, i.e. The Messiah, an epithet of Jesus.
But, except, however. Neuter plural of allos; properly, other things, i.e. contrariwise.

parse: Verb - Aorist Participle Passive - Nominative Masculine Plural
str2: A prolongation and middle voice form of a primary verb; to cause to be, i.e. to become, used with great latitude.
An eyewitness, spectator, looker-on. From epi and a presumed derivative of optanomai; a looker-on.
That, that one there, yonder. From ekei; that one (neuter) thing); often intensified by the article prefixed.
(divine) majesty or magnificence, glory. From megaleios; superbness, i.e. Glory or splendor.
